narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course mainly directed students to apply historical background to modern political and social issues in China.
We learned not only about Chinese history but also about how it connects to the present. It was very useful to understand better the Chinese perspective towards China's issues in the present.
History of the Song and Qing dynasties, as well as Wuhan and COVID.
I learned a lot about Chinese history, and quite a bit about recent events surrounding COVID.
knowledge of chinese history

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course does a great job at looking at modern sociopolitical issues in China. That being said, I would just barely call it a history course. The name is incredibly misleading because in no way do we take a survey of Chinese history starting at the present and then working back into the past. Really what it should be called is "China in the Present with Brief, Miscellaneous Looks at the Past." If you are looking for a real Chinese history class, then this is not it for you. The course also does well enough in discussing bias in sources and help students analyze this bias, but another pitfall is the professor. She can be pleasant at times, especially in a one-on-one, but her tone can often be condescending during section, and that is incredibly inappropriate, especially when we are discussing topics that are subjective and students or the TF are giving their own opinions. However, the TF is wonderful and very knowledgable on Chinese history and modern events. Lastly, I just found the course to be poorly organized. There was no logical progression of the history discussed in class and the organization was more centered around a non-meaningful arrangement of events in modern China such as "protests" or "family life," while the course title suggests the progression to start in modern China and work backwards until the Song Dynasty.
strength was the instructors recorded lectures, she really put a lot of time into them and they were very professional.

One of the midterm options was to write an op-Ed in the style of the New York Times in less than 1.5 hours. We were graded on quality of writing. How can anyone produce anything of quality in 1.5 hours?

This course being entirely remote made it more difficult to engage with the material, especially for a history class such as this one. However, the course material was interesting and Professor Hansen definitely knows what she is talking about.
It is very well organized and the readings are very interesting.
Would appreciate if lecture notes could be uploaded! Also more clarity on assignment requirements/grading.

Strengths: GREAT PROFESSOR!!! also, the course material was really interesting! 
Weakness: kinda of a lot of reading, but its doable if you schedule it throughout the week.
great class, no complaints

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The prerecorded lectures ended up as a disaster. While the beginning of the semester, the recordings were fine, towards the middle of the semester, the quality became nearly quite bad with horrible audio quality that was difficult to hear and poor video that made it difficult to see the slide shows. Also, the canvas page with the lecture links was difficult to navigate because the links were all just numbered with no indication of the date or topic of the lecture, which could have greatly improved the navigability of the page. The recorded lectures were also not very engaging. Section was on zoom as any other class, so this was as any other zoom class would be. The professor was also understanding of technical difficulties that could have caused any issues in submitting work or attending section, which was relieving.
Virtual discussions and prerecorded lectures were very good, but I would increase the amount of discussion time.

Her recorded lectures were great! She hired a camera man to record her videos and the frame changed every so often, which helped keep me engaged (easier to re-engage when frame changed because it helped me refocus after zoning out).
the best that a history class could do virtually

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not recommend this course to anyone looking for an actual education on Chinese history, which is disappointing to say considering it is the only Chinese history course I have found that covers anything beyond the 20th century. However, if you are more interested in presentism and the modern face of Chinese history, then getting past Hansen's unpleasant condescension, I would recommend the course.
No
Definitely. Very interesting and very well organized. The professor is also amazing.
Absolutely!! Professor Hansen is amazing and the course is super interesting!
yes, its a great history class

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lecture, weekly section
We also had live virtual discussion section.
Recorded lecture
Recorded lecture + live sections every week.
We had live, online discussion sections once a week.
section and canvas assignments
